B000PTYP5C|4.0|Well well. Dream Theater return in fine form on this album. Train of Thought and Octavarium really didnt impress me, I've STILL got my jaw dropped from Scenes From A Memory, and I was hoping for an album more in that vein. I'll agree with what one reviewer said: some good, some bad. Track by track rundown:    1. In The Presence Of Enemies Pt. 1 - 8/10 - nice strong start to the album.     2. Forsaken - 10/10 - my favorite track. The piano line is like something out of Images and Words-era DT, and the way the solo comes in (and the solo itself) is goosebump-inducing. Petrucci's phrasing = godly.    3. Constant Motion - 9/10 - Can someone say Metallica? But Dream Theater have never been ashamed of their influences, and this is a finer song than anything Metallica have released in the last 17 years or so. The breakdown that leads into the solo part is Dance of Eternity-ish, my fave part.     4. The Dark Eternal Night - 7/10 - some killer riffs, a great chorus, but I just cant let go of the fact that Petrucci said this song is literally about \\"monsters\\". I'm also not a big fan of the vocals in the verse.     5. Repentance - 9/10 - revisiting Portnoy's AA theme, this is a really haunting track. Guest...wouldnt say vocal appearance, more like talk appearance by Steven Wilson of Porcupine Tree (my fave band of all time) def adds to the mix.     6. Prophets of War - 7/10 - Cool riff, interesting song. Kind of gets boring after a while though.    7. The Ministry Of Lost Souls - 9/10 - I really dig this song. A mixture of much of what Dream Theater is in a single track. The melodies are fantastic.     8. In The Presence Of Enemies Pt 2 - 6/10 - it might grow on me, but so far this track isnt doing anything for me. Definitely not what I wouldve enjoyed the album closing on.     Overall, this is a good album. Recommended for fans of DT, but if youre just starting out with the band, pick up SFAM, Awake, and I&W.
B000AARKOO|5.0|The action never stops and it's just tons of fun.  The special effects are insane.  It's a summer action flick with a brain.
B00005BL2A|5.0|I don't think any album has ever grown on me quite like Exciter has. And I don't believe that time has simply made it more palatable - I'm pretty sure now in retrospect that the main reason I was initially disappointed was because it followed my favorite DM album, Ultra, so the bar was impossibly high. Also, it's undeniably more subdued than the previous albums. I love mellow stuff, but I wasn't expecting it, so it took me a little by surprise.  <br />  <br />Fast forward a half dozen years and now this is one of the DM albums I find myself going back to the most. I absolutely love it, and can't believe there was ever a time I didn't. I love that this album is different from the others in that it's the most low-key and romantic. It's such a beautiful album, and showcases elements of this great band that are not necessarily highlighted in other albums. The only song I still don't love is \\"Breathe,\\" but even that one I like a lot more than I used to. On the other hand, I think \\"Comatose\\" is one of the best Gore-sung tracks in their entire catalog (bizarre as it is). \\"Dream On,\\" \\"Shine,\\" \\"When the Body Speaks,\\" \\"Dead of Night,\\" \\"Freelove,\\" \\"I Feel Loved,\\" \\"I Am You,\\" and \\"Goodnight Lovers\\" are every bit as good as all the classics. The production on this album is superb, and often reminiscent of Bjork's Vespertine.  <br />  <br />If you gave up on this album early on and tossed it aside, calling it crap, I suggest popping it in sometime (preferably on a beautiful summer night) and giving it another chance. You may find that with the passage of time, you have changed your mind.
0141439580|4.0|Jane Austen's \\"Emma\\" is a good read. I consider Austen a mistress of dialogue and of creating very colourful, vivid and almost touchable characters. These two points make \\"Emma\\" a very enjoyable novel.  The only thing I found weak - as it is in other Austen's books - is the sudden turns in the story, events that have an incredibly atrificial (or deus ex machina) taste to them.It almost feels like Austen has tried to twist the entangled situations in such a way as to ensure a undisputable happy ending.  Despite of the shaky storyline, the main character - Emma Woodhouse - comes through as credible and realistic. She has her faults, she makes mistakes, and inspite her wit and intelligence, she is young and inexperienced and this makes her very much like any other young woman in the 21st centrury - a young woman who has to go through some blunders in order to learn about life and herself.  It is Emma's character that makes the whole book worthy of purchasing and adding to one's library. I would suggest \\"Emma\\" above any other Jane Austen's classics for it is obviously the most mature book of them all.

B00005JA2B|5.0|Few bands can say that they have written and recorded a song that can be considered an all time classic.  On Kansas's 4th album the instant you hear the opening  harmony vocal arrangement of \\"Carry On My Wayward Son\\" you can't help but be hooked.  I have heard this song a million times over the years and I still crank it up and enjoy I when it comes on the radio.  It ranks right up with \\"Stairway To Heaven\\", \\"Freebird\\" and others and one of the all time most enduring classic rock songs.  \\"Leftoverture\\" is the album that would break the band into the mainstream.  Almost overnight they went from opening act status to headlining arenas.  The great thing about it was that they hit these commercial heights without compromising the quality of their music.  This is a great album from start to finish and shows the continuing maturity of the Livgren / Walsh songwriting tandem.  Musically everything here is killer.  There are no super long progressive rock epics on this one, but there is still plenty to please the prog rock fan with the 8 minute quirky closer \\"Magnum Opus\\" to the shorter, but still brilliant \\"Cheyenne Anthem\\" and \\"\\"Miracles Out Of Nowhere\\".  The rest of the album is also dazzling.  \\"The Wall\\" remains a live favorite.  \\"What's On My Mind\\", \\"Opus Insert\\" and \\"Questions Of My Childhood\\" are shorter, but great in their own way.  You really can't go wrong with this album as it deserves the level of success that it reached.  This is also the album where the first hints of Kerry Livgren's conversion to Christianity begin to show up in the lyrics.  At this point it is still pretty subtle, but it would eventually be the cause of Steve Walsh leaving the band a few years later.

0440237688|5.0|Now, as technology  touch every inch of our existence, how much we think and to what extent should we allow them into our lives?  <br />  <br />  <br />The reason I am reflecting is that I read a book entitled The Giver which  is written by Lois Lowry.  This book actually is for a book for children, and in fact have won a good number of awards, including the John Newbery Medal for most distinguished contribution to American Literature for Children.  It was originally read by my son who told me it was good, and I took it. Incidentally, it is always good to take an active interest in what your kids are reading, and ocassionally won't harm much if you actually read it as well.  That i believe, always create good talking points with your kids.  <br />  <br />The story is quite thought provoking, and basically centers on a community in which the people, years into the future, use technology try to create a world where everything is perfect.  It might seem bizarre, but overall, it does seem plausible that if we are too overzealous and if we could do it, we will be headed in that direction.  <br />  <br />When you consider that a lot of grief or sorrow is because of poverty, then solve poverty.  A lot of bad things come because of war, then use technology to acquire peace.  If hunger is the issue, then insure that there won't be any hunger.  But the policymakers in this book went beyond that -- they noted that a lot of grief comes from pain, so they were able to work out the perfect medicines that will cure pain and disease.  Much grief comes from love, envy, anger,  and greed, so basically they develop the pills to control that as well.  <br />  <br />If you consider that people also becomes sorrowful because they make the wrong choice so they eliminated choice as well.  So in this community, a committee of experts make the evaluation what jobs you get  ( depending on detailed recordings and observations on your interests and talents), who you marry, and also they have systems to insure that only healthy kids are born, and these are assigned to the right 'nurturers' to insure comformance of the system.  <br />  <br />In short, this was supposedly a story about a society where there is supposedly no fear, or no pain.  Something like nirvana, or heaven, where everything works and is programmed to be just right.  There is nothing unexpected, unusual or even inconvenient.  Everything works according to plan, just like clockwork.  <br />  <br />In short, the author perceives that we can actually not only use technology to improve our lives, but if we are not controlled, we will be moving forward to using it to shield us from everything that would cause sadness or grief, and if we allow technology to do that, sooner or later, we will come up with technology to do precisely that.  <br />  <br />Isn't that what we all want?  Or where we are heading?  <br />  <br />The hero, a 12 year old boy was selected to receive special training which allows him to experience true pain and pleasure.  He later tries to opt out of the system, because he believes being 'human' is something that is different.  Which begs the question that if you don't know sorrow, would you know happiness?  If you don't know or have experienced failure, would you appreciate what it is to be successful.  If you never experience hunger, would you know how lucky you are to always have food in the t   able?  <br />  <br /> Now , more and more, as our society advance, we do start to being able to get practically everything we want, but we think we are doing our children a favor by doing everything to shield them from the bad things that we as parents also have experienced before.  We shield them from pain, from hunger, from anything inconvenient or anything closely resembling hard work?  <br />  <br />Are we therefore using technology the right way?  Is that how we envision technology to increasingly play in our lives - shield us from the real challenges of the world?  <br />  <br />by: wilson ng  <br />My blog at :  [...]

B000BVRWJA|5.0|This watch is definitely an eye catcher. Great value. Excellent entry level swiss watch.
B000PFUAO6|5.0|After listening to this album several times, I have come to the conclusion (unwilling at first) that this is one of Dream Theater's best releases, right below \\"Images and Words\\" and \\"Scenes From A Memory.\\" As mentioned by other reviewers, it contains a large mixture of the sounds that Dream Theater has become known for, as well as some newer surprises.   I think its worth going through each song on this disc.       \\"In the Presence of Enemies\\" (Pts 1&2; it will played as one song live) is an amazing epic; yes, several of the lyrics in the second part are a bit cheesy. But it doesn't matter... the composition and playing on this epic are both amazing, and the vocals fit each and every part of the song perfectly. In case anyone is wondering what this song is about, it is based on a manhwa (Korean comic book) called Priest. Several of the lyrics are taken directly from it, or modified from the original print version. Dream Theater does an excellent job of putting this fantasy epic into musical form, and this is probably the best song on the CD. Part 1 begins the disc and Part 2 ends it because, as Mike Portnoy said, it was the perfect song to begin the CD and the perfect song to end it.        Some people have criticized \\"Forsaken\\" for its lyrics and simplicity, but these accusations shouldn't take away from the fact that this is very good song. The riff is one the best Petrucci has played, and his fills/the solo make the song what it is. Aside from the guitar work, Jordan's piano intro is a haunting one, and sets the tone for the rest of the song. A good tune with passionate vocals by James.       \\"Constant Motion\\" does sound like Metallica for much of the intro and verses, but the middle instrumental section of the song is fantastic and in true Dream Theater style. This song deals with the band's direction to some degree and with a band member's psychological state to another. It ends up being a really good rocker that is one of the best on the CD.       I was somewhat surprised by \\"The Dark Eternal Night\\" when I first saw the in-studio clip of it on Youtube. Not just by the heaviness of the guitar and other instruments (since Dream Theater has done that before) but by the intense vocals. I got used to them eventually, and also came to realize that this is yet another incredible song. Like \\"Constant Motion,\\" and actually like most of the tracks on this CD, it is the instrumental section in the middle of the song that raises it from good to amazing. It sounds similar to \\"The Dance of Eternity,\\" not necessarily in terms of notes but in terms of the fractured, anything-goes type feel that comes from all the rhythm changes and ridiculous piano/guitar riffs. The solo is amazingly fast, and the song has a nice outro as well (with a nice improv continuum solo by Jordan).    \\"Repentance\\" is an interesting song, and one that took me a couple listens to really appreciate. It is a Pink-Floyd style epic, and can be a bit boring at times. However, the soft guitar and keyboards in the first half of the song provide an excellent sonic background and a definite (and in my opinion, good) contrast to the heaviness of \\"The Glass Prison,\\" \\"This Dying Soul,\\" and \\"The Root of All Evil.\\" They fit the subject matter of the song as well. The second half of the song begins after an amazing lyrical solo by Petrucci (yes Gilmour fans, there are vague similarities), and isn't as good but still fascinating. It is fun trying to figure out which voice belongs to which guest singer... and other than that this song is really to relax to. It comes at the perfect point in the album as well, right after and right before more typical Dream Theater insanity.       \\"Prophets of War\\" is the weakest track on this CD, but it is still a good song. James Labrie's vocals (the only ones he wrote on this CD) are very relevant, and get his message across effectively. The heaviness and background vocals are what make this song a good one, aside from the lyrics. What is there to not like about this song? The keyboard riff, a bit too similar to Never Enough (and Muse, according to many people... I haven't listened to them before), and I guess the simplicity of this tune. I like it when Dream Theater does more complex song structures, as well as more instrumental sections, because those are definitely their strengths. Well, moving on to the next song...       This is probably my favorite song on the album, \\"The Ministry of Lost Souls.\\" It begins as a ballad, the lyrics and vocals are very powerful and fascinating... it is worth looking up what this song is about. This song is simply amazing from start to finish... the solos are two of the best I have ever heard, and the guitar melody in the last part of the song is the perfect way to end it. There is nothing else to say... you have to hear it.    So that pretty much sums up the entire album... I like it about as much as \\"Awake,\\" less than their best two albums (mentioned above), and more than \\"Octavarium,\\" \\"Train of Thought,\\" \\"Six Degrees...,\\" and \\"Falling into Infinity.\\" Overall, it is another step forward into history for Dream Theater... another amazing progressive metal album. I highly recommend it.

1419359827|2.0|Unfortunately, I bought the CD set, which I believe was narrated by the author.  Big mistake.  The guy is very enamored with himself and he could have condensed the book (CD) by about 75% and still got the point across.    I worked in Sales at Northwestern Mutual and my company pushed us hard to live by this book.  I ended up spending a fortune on lunches and dinners and didn't get quite the amount of business that I had expected.  I think the author must have a vested interest in the restaurant business.    I could probably boil it down to one simple concept ... the most effective way to network is to think about how many ways you can give value, provide leads, or be of service to those in your professional network.  It's like what President Kennedy once challenged the nation, \\"Ask not what the country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country.\\"  The same goes for professional networking and that is what this book is primarily about.    The book will cost you about as much as a meal, and then you will spend thousands of dollars on business meals afterwards.  Save yourself the time and money, just be very generous and giving at professional networking events.  Try to serve others and though good karma, it will be returned to you.

0765348780|5.0|I found this title while searching for something that could satisfy my hunger for depth and grit while I awaited the next installment in GRRMs \\"A Song of Ice and Fire\\".  I had begun feeling like there just wasn't anything in the fantasy genre that could come close to the \\"grown up\\" feel of that series and though I enjoy reading the novels put out by other contemporary fanasy writers, I have been deeply spoiled by the refreshingly grey-scale world woven by Martin.  In searching for other contemporary fantasy authors that could engender in me the same depth of feeling and suspense that Martin has, I came across several lists in which \\"Gardens of the Moon\\" (and it's subsequent volumes) were listed alongside the titles that I have come to deeply enjoy.  My first taste of Erikson was a pleasant one indeed.    In this book you will find very little in the way of clear-cut good and evil (even a demon can be cute in this world when it is kept as a pet) but you will find much of the refreshing shades of grey that make the world feel real despite it's fantasy heritage.  The cast is huge and the races are many, and I'll admit it can be daunting at times.  That said, the author never seems to talk \\"down\\" to you or insult your intelligence with ultra-convenient and utterly unbelievable plot twists.  In addition, the book engenders a rare but true feeling of suspense brought on by the fact that the main characters are not necessarily going to make it alive...one of the main things that made Martin's books so great to me.  The question then becomes \\"will he get out of this\\" rather than \\"how will he get out of this.\\"    On the downside, it can be difficult to keep track of what race is what and who is on who's side, but some of that can be attributed to the fact that many of the characters are simply on their own side, rather than backing the cause of one of the main fighting influences in the story.  I also get the feeling that as you continue with this series, much of this will become more familiar as I was much more accustomed to following the goings-on by the end of the book than I was in the beginning.    In summary, with a little grit, a lot of sorcery, some sword and a fair measure of intelligence, Erikson has managed to pen a tale that truly is fit to rub shoulders with the likes of the best the fantasy genre has to offer and leaves the overwhelming majority of his contemporaries in the dust.  And while he's not Martin, he's comparable and he writes faster -- meaning I'll have something to read and keep me happy while I patiently wait for Martin to shuffle into his publisher with the next installment of ASOIAF in tow.  I highly recommend Gardens of the Moon.

B000AXSN5G|4.0|Like Johnny Cash, Neil's been everywhere, man. Which means that the occasional quiet, unassuming, unpretentious country-folk record is perfectly welcome. This happens to be a quiet, unassuming, unpretentious country-folk record. Draw your own conclusions. This is a good record for sure, but it's a couple songs short of being a crowning achievement like, say, After the Gold Rush. It's not overproduced, it's melodic, it's relaxing, there's a horn section that sounds good but slightly out-of-place. Really, what else do you need to know? Oh yeah, what songs are good and what songs aren't. My favorite is the intense \\"No Wonder\\", followed by the longish, reflective title track and the depressed \\"Painter\\" - I also enjoy the quiet, brief \\"Fallin' off the Face of the Earth\\" and the hymnal \\"When God Made Me\\" (though the choir is a bit much). I suppose that, if I was a jerk, I could slag \\"Far from Home\\" for being exaggerated and syrupy, but the truth is I like that one too. It's just exaggerated and syrupy, that's all. Now when Neil opens up a bottle of Aunt Jemima and pours it everywhere, like he does on the Elvis tribute \\"He Was the King\\", \\"It's a Dream\\" and \\"Here for You\\", that's where the problems start to set in. I hope you like cheese, because between those three songs there's a lot of gorgonzola. Good thing that he mostly forgets about the aforementioned metaphorical dairy products and pancake toppings, and chooses instead to go for a quiet, subdued, genuinely heartfelt album in a day and age where self-centered angst means money in the bank.

0743298020|4.0|It's no coincidence that Diane Setterfield's debut novel is about a young woman whose passion is reading nineteenth century novels, since her book reads like one.  The story of Margaret Lee and the recluse author Vida Winter has all the delicious twists and turns of romance, mystery, family lineage, jealousy, madness, murder and love. All of the things that you can expect from Bronte, Austen, Dickens, George, and the rest of the literary cast from Victorian England you can expect to get here from Setterfield.<br /><br />This book is well-written and  peopled with believable, complex, and often ambiguous characters.  Also, like much of Victorian literature, \\"The Thirteenth Tale\\" has many meta-fictional qualities, since it is a story within a story within a story.  A schoolteacher herself, Setterfield is clearly a bibliophile, whose love for reading often transcends into drawing attention to its own fictionality.  Lastly and most memorably, though is the plot of the novel.  While I don't want to give away anything, I will say that the plot is as serpentine as one might expect it to be, given its influences.  Fraught with coincidence and surprise, I found the plot almost predictable, but in a comforting, coming-home sort of way.<br /><br />I enjoyed this first effort from this author, and yet I expect that her next novel will be completely different,  since she has explored this genre so thoroughly already.  I eagerly await to see what other literary frontiers she plans on retracing.

B000P2A256|4.0|Normally (although not deliberately), I tend to ignore bands like Maroon 5. A bluntly commercial band with this much corporate support does not need my backing, so I usually leave it alone and let the marketplace decide for itself. The world at large seems to understand Avril Lavigne, Nickelback and Fall Out Boy a lot better than I do anyway, so voicing my opinion about the musical value of these acts would feel like screaming at the wall. Usually, I simply look the other way, but I've been listening to \\"It Won't Be Soon Before Long\\" for a few weeks now, and it has me believing that Maroon 5 can justify the hype.<br />Maroon 5's last album, \\"Songs About Jane,\\" may have been released in 2002, but I didn't hear a note of it until two years later, when the relentless push from the band's backers finally ignited the jet fuel that lifted the band to stardom. Apparently, I wasn't alone in this regard, since the band took home a Grammy award for best new artist three years later, in 2005. Naturally, that brought them a lot of attention, but I figured they would suffer the same fate as many previous `Best New Artist' winners and vanish into the night sky. \\"It Won't Be Soon Before Long\\" renders my prediction obsolete. The production is damn near perfect, but in a mid-`80s, Quincy Jones kind of way that often gets in the way of allowing the band to establish its own identity. There is a slick, funky sheen to the best songs, and vocalist Adam Levine dishes out melodies that are flawlessly polished to a full luster. Imagine Maxwell covering a Michael Jackson hit with an ace rock band for support, and you'll get close to the essence of this song collection.<br />The subject matter is also intriguing. There are lots of cheating songs on the disk, and lots of lyrics that will break the hearts of hormone-addled romantics. If his words are remotely autobiographical, then Levine could be the poster boy for the lovelorn, even when his sentiments are shopworn and clich&eacute;d; on \\"Won't Go Home Without You,\\" he knows the girl was right to ditch him, but swears that he needs \\"one more chance to make it right.\\" On \\"Nothing Lasts Forever,\\" he sings \\"I love you but I'm letting go\\" while \\"Can't Stop (Thinking About You)\\" is self-explanatory. \\"Wake Up Call\\" is a bit more blatant - \\"Caught you in the morning with another one in my bed. 0143038419|1.0|I had seen all the good reviews on this book and since I am an avid traveler and reader, I was excited to read a memoir from an excellent writer. I was sorely disappointed.    Foremost, I did not even finish the book which is rare for me. I made it halfway through India before I was so disheartened by Ms. Gilbert's narrative voice. There is a difference between sounding funny, candid and likable and sounding petty, conceited and fickle.     While I was reading this book I was genuinely surprised by the lack of empathy Ms. Gilbert had for anyone. Every situation, every comment, every sidestory pointed squarely to herself and her personal problems. I was shocked that she had lived in Rome and India for months and had not been affected by the poverty and corruption. I suppose if you are so caught up in your own problems and all your own shopping and eating that it's difficult to understand that other people around you have far worse problems. Maybe, just maybe looking outside of yourself and giving of yourself you will find self-worth and purpose, self-worth that goes beyond buying new underwear or eating a gorgeous meal or bragging about having a meditation high.     If you want to read a real journey of discovery, love, Italy and food, I would highly recommend Marlena De Blasi's A Thousand Days in Venice. Her narrative voice is far superior and she reveals larger truths from her personal experiences while getting to really know the local people and appreciating their culture.
B000N4SHOE|3.0|Reunited for the first time since the stylishly acclaimed romantic comedy `Down with Love', stars Renee Zellweger and Ewan McGregor again light up the screen, except this time they are devoid of the slick, candy coated perfection that made their last outing so spectacularly delicious. However, in the story chronicling the mushy love life of Beatrix Potter, the acclaimed author of whimsical children's stories like \\"The Tale of Peter Rabbit\\", the duo get to continue their onscreen chemistry in a new way, as bumbling and awkward early twentieth century lovers.<br /><br />In Hollywood it is rare and refreshing to find a director who makes films because he is captivated by the story, but for Chris Noonan, who helmed this lush and lavish period piece, `Miss Potter' marks his first feature film since the phenomenally successful 1995 movie `Babe'. While there are a few nods to swine sprinkled throughout `Miss Potter', Noonan's new film focuses on human nuances more so than talking animals.<br /><br />With beautiful performances comprised from the film's stars, `Miss Potter' is an intriguing examination of an important literary figure which is designed for the whole family to enjoy. On the surface an unmarried, thirty-something daughter of a British aristocrat who spends her days not only painting small farm animals, but talking to her work as if they were living and breathing individuals, might serve as a beautiful case study for schizophrenia; however Zellweger's strong performance as Beatrix Potter makes the nuanced character come to life in charming and delightful ways.<br /><br />Of course half the fun of her character comes from her rebellious love for the tradesmen Norman Warne (McGregor), who just happens to be her publisher too. In a film that is filled with lavish, golden cinematography, doing justice to Potter's own watercolor illustrations, it is the moment when these two lovers culminate their relationship with an iconic kiss on the fog filled London train tracks that `Miss Potter' completely enraptures you.<br /><br />The epic challenge for Potter, even more difficult than getting her \\"Bunny Book\\" published, was winning her aristocratic parents over with the idea of marriage to Norman Warne. With a Shakespearean refusal to budge, Potter's parents force the author to seek out other ways for her to marry her true love. When she decides she might have the income to move out on her own Potter humbly asks her banker if she has enough money for a small home, to which he replies that not only could she afford a house, but several estates as well.<br /><br />As fun and family friendly as a great deal of the first act may seem, `Miss Potter' does have its darker moments which is sure to catch audiences looking for the next `Finding Neverland' off guard. When an important figure in Potter's life passes away due to illness, suddenly her entire future is in flux, a plot point which is sure to confuse younger audiences. While death may be an important subject for children to comprehend, it may be a subject that parents of young Peter Rabbit fans might not be ready to broach just yet.<br /><br />For their latest pairing on the big screen Zellweger and McGregor deliver another magical, yet decidedly different romance that is sure to delight audiences of all ages. For his first film since `Babe', director Noonan doesn't seem to be rusty at all when it comes to telling a story on film, and with a little luck we will hopefully get more cinematic fair from him. In the case of his second picture in over a decade I can only sum up the film with this statement: That'll do Potter, that'll do.<br /><br />-Joe Russo, MoviePulse.netompletely enraptures you.     The epic challenge for Potter, even more difficult than getting her \\"Bunny Book\\" published, was winning her aristocratic parents over with the idea of marriage to Norman Warne. With a Shakespearean refusal to budge, Potter's parents force the author to seek out other ways for her to marry her true love. When she decides she might have the income to move out on her own Potter humbly asks her banker if she has enough money for a small home, to which he replies that not only could she afford a house, but several estates as well.     As fun and family friendly as a great deal of the first act may seem, `Miss Potter' does have its darker moments which is sure to catch audiences looking for the next `Finding Neverland' off guard. When an important figure in Potter's life passes away due to illness, suddenly her entire future is in flux, a plot point which is sure to confuse younger audiences. While death may be an important subject for children to comprehend, it may be a subject that parents of young Peter Rabbit fans might not be ready to broach just yet.    For their latest pairing on the big screen Zellweger and McGregor deliver another magical, yet decidedly different romance that is sure to delight audiences of all ages. For his first film since `Babe', director Noonan doesn't seem to be rusty at all when it comes to telling a story on film, and with a little luck we will hopefully get more cinematic fair from him. In the case of his second picture in over a decade I can only sum up the film with this statement: That'll do Potter, that'll do.         -Joe Russo, MoviePulse.net
1883217040|3.0|This book is very good and I recommend it to any serious music student.  I learned a lot from it and it gave me plenty of new information and insights.  It is also valuable as a reference with excellent indicies and appendices, for example a long list of contrafacts based upon standard song forms.  My main criticism of it is that it is very piano-centric.  Most examples are given in complex two-handed piano-score format which is great if you can sight read complex piano parts, but are not immediately helpful if piano is your second or third instrument.  Also, examples and contexts reflect the author's own personal tastes heavily.  There is nothing really wrong with these things, but for a book that seems to present itself as the authoritative text on jazz theory, it's not.  I think Bert Ligon's series of books presents a more comprehensive, accessible, and balanced overview of jazz theory, and is more oriented towards musicians in general, not only pianists.

0385522401|4.0|This little book can be polished off in an afternoon, and I found great pleasure sitting in the park this afternoon with Ian McEwan's new story, watching young lovers stroll by, hand in hand. It is impossible to read this without feeling afresh how arcane and bewildering human pairing and mating seems, particularly to the uninitiated. As Florence and Edward fumble through their wedding night, one can almost see their parents in the shadows and tumult of the bedclothes restraining the couple's zippers and buttons. These two young people have been shaped by the absences and excesses of the older generation; McEwan's marital bed is crowded.The writing is deft, with his perfect imagery and elegant simplicity. This is not his most ambitious work, but it is a wonderfully distilled portrait of two very decent, ordinary people who want to grow ever closer, but haven't acquired a language to do let them do it. When their bodies betray them, shame and humiliation twist what few words they can summon.    The ending was a bit tepid, like drinking yesterday's Breakfast Twining and biscuits,but I highly recommend spending a day \\"On Chesil Beach\\".

B000002JKA|5.0|Dream Theater's latest three albums (Systematic Chaos, Octavarium, and Train of Thought), though all solid albums by lesser standards than what the band must live up to, had left me a little bit forgetful as to why I considered Dream Theater my favorite band for such a long period of my adolescent life. So I turned back to the albums which started it all- Awake. And though it has been years since I bought the album, and probably at least one year since I gave it a good listen, the album's magic has not worn off at all. With \\"Awake\\" Dream Theater created an album that was so undeniably cool! Heavy enough to be considered Metal, and Progressive to the bone, but lacking almost all the cheesy characteristic that turn most music fans away from those genres. As I listen through Dream Theater's discography once again, I am forced to admit that \\"Awake\\" was probably the best moment for each member of the band (at that time), both lyrically and musically.<br /><br />John Petrucci sounds better on this album than any other. His guitar sounds are crunchier on here than on previous efforts, and the Ibanez he used in these days sounds much better than that Ernie Ball set-up he uses now. He doesn't try to impress with Steve Vai-esque solos in every song, and he doesn't need to. The solos in \\"Scarred\\" and \\"Erotomania\\" should be enough to convince any listener of his talents.  Lyrically, this album includes his best work- \\"A Mind Beside Itself\\".<br /><br />Surprisingly enough, James LaBrie is also a Most Valuable Player on this disc. For the first, and last, time ever in Dream Theater history, his vocals are raw and emotional. He screams the lines that need to be screamed, and when a gentler tone is necessary he delivers it flawlessly. LaBrie is not a bad singer at all, though his voice is often the object of complaint by Dream Theater fans. I think that this is because the rest of the band does not give him room to be himself on the albums, but I will say this- there are few singers that can deliver with the quality of emotion and uniqueness as LaBrie.<br /><br />Finally, this album is Kevin Moore's good-bye album. He was, without a doubt, Dream Theater's most tasteful keyboard player. When he left, the band lost quite a big chunk of it's character. But the band also lost the person who was probably it's greatest lyricist. Moore shines on Awake, both lyrically and musically, more so than on any album he has participated in in the past of future.<br /><br />Awake was a special moment for not only Dream Theater but all of Progressive Music. Dream Theater brought dark, depth, and passion to a genre that is often criticized for lacking it, and since Awake this kind of magic has only reincarnated itself in bands like Pain of Salvation and Opeth. Dream Theater will never make an album like Awake again. Truly, Awake is their masterpiece.iver with the quality of emotion and uniqueness as LaBrie. But the band also lost the person who was probably it's greatest lyricist. Moore shines on Awake, both lyrically and musically, more so than on any album he has participated in in the past of future.    Awake was a special moment for not only Dream Theater but all of Progressive Music. Dream Theater brought dark, depth, and passion to a genre that is often criticized for lacking it, and since Awake this kind of magic has only reincarnated itself in bands like Pain of Salvation and Opeth. Dream Theater will never make an album like Awake again. Truly, Awake is their masterpiece.

B000K1Z3ZQ|3.0|Spoilers Ahead:    This novel is set in the Igbo homeland in what is now southeastern Nigeria in the late 1800s/early 1900s. I read about three-quarters of the book before I began to appreciate it.     Up to then I'd disliked the main character, Okonkwo, an important person in the village whose major traits were harsh anger, pride and inflexibility, finding him one-sided and uninteresting. I felt the description was plodding and little of importance was happening, and wasn't greatly interested in the village life. Much of the novel was concerned mainly with his point of view, and his interactions with the other, relatively minor characters were unexciting. When a dramatic event occurred, such as his accidental shooting of a villager that led to his exile, it was described in a flat, undramatic tone that seemed inappropriate and puzzled me.     I couldn't help comparing this novel unfavorably with another I happened to be reading, Palace Walk, by Naguib Mahfouz, with its complex, many-sided protagonist, the many other strongly developed people in his family, the dramatic interaction between them, and the rich world around them that was reasonably familiar.     It was only after reading some background material that I could begin to understand how Achebe's novel aimed to recreate a vibrant culture that had existed before colonization on its own terms, with its oral tradition, rituals and taboos, and guardian spirits, and show what had been lost. The focus on a period before colonization and the depiction of the whites as interlopers has been called innovative for its time. Likewise the use of language in the words of the villagers, instead of pidgin.     A scholar of African lit, Bernth Lindfors, has described the book like this: \\"Instead of representing Africa as a barbarous wilderness where savages lived in a permanent state of anarchy until the white man came bringing peace, law, order, religion, and a 'higher' form of civilization, Achebe showed how Africans led decent, moral lives in well-regulated societies that placed strict legal and religious constraints on human behavior. Indeed, according to Achebe, things did not fall apart in Africa until Europe intruded and set everything off balance by introducing alien codes which Africans were then told to live by. Europe did not bring light and peace . . . it brought chaos and confusion\\" (quotation from the preface to the Anchor Book of Modern African Short Stories).     At the same time, Achebe showed how some elements from outside the traditional culture, such as Christianity, weren't merely imposed from above but appealed strongly to some of the Igbo, especially those at the bottom of the society, and those who felt the new religion was more powerful. And he showed that the traditional society had its own internal problems and was ready for change. Achebe himself has been quoted as saying, \\"My sympathies were not entirely with Okonkwo . . . . Life just has to go on and if you refuse to accept changes, then, tragic though it may be, you are swept aside\\" (quotation from Under African Skies: Modern African Stories).     The conventional action came almost entirely in the last quarter of the novel, when the encroaching missionaries, together with the trading culture and the colonizers' threat of force, began to overwhelm the village. Although I can't say I identified with the main character even at the end, by then I could better appreciate the loss of the village culture.
0575077859|5.0|I haven't read anything resembling fantasy for a few years after being an avid fan in my teens and twenties (yes that makes me 30 something). I picked this book up on a whim because it was put in a 'Humour' section, and deliberately so apparently. It certainly isn't a book that should be in the humour section, but it is the sort of fantasy book that draws well on broad human experience such that if you picked a page at random you may well think its a comedic book, or another and think you're reading an adventure/war story, another a tragic relationship drama. Overall, however, it is a great fantasy novel with enthralling characters.    It is this, I think that makes 'The Blade Itself' so enjoyable. The writing style sees you drawn into the story from the character's point and you easily identify with them rather than feeling like you're watching events unfold as a observer who happens to know what the main characters are thinking. Further, the characters seem to weave in to the plot that unfolds around them rather than simply being the plot itself which is a criticism I have of much fantasy writing where the greater world seems to repetitiously revolve around the main character(s). Further, the characters generally have complexity, depth and mystery about them that makes them decidedly believable and, more importantly, intimately relatable too.     The other BIG plus for me is that Abercrombie writes in a style that shows  enough attention to detail without getting bogged down in unnecessary explanation. The universe unfolds rather than being spelled out in ultra-fine detail, and this shows the skill of the writer; This will always be a matter of subjectivity of course, but lesser authors seem compelled to 'explain' through their characters the broader setting. Of course Abercrombie has to do that at times, but it is kept to a minimum and avoids anything but essential detail which keeps the pace moving at what I felt was just right. It thus has the feeling of beingan epic without the 'I will now use this book as a door stop once I've finshed' size about it.    Finally, it is certainly graphic in parts, but what I would call pointless or unnecessary gore is rare - if that makes sense.     I would give this 4.5 stars if I could with the only draw back being the lack of any sense of 'tie up' to conclude the book. I understand this is a balancing act, but it would have been nice to feel that there was some finality to the first book to ease the wait for the second and third volume. As it is, it finishes completely open ended, which might be tad annoying for some.
B000OYC3J8|5.0|With a buzzing bass line, thumping beat, and sudden bursts of guitar and percussion (and a squealing guitar solo), The White Stripes announce their return with lead off single \\"Icky thump\\", which is already a UK #2 smash.<br /><br />\\"Icky Thump\\" is the Stripes 6th studio release, and the first since Jack White's detour to his Grammy nominated side project, The Raconteurs last year, and its a plethora of great edgy blues/garage rock songs. The album has a fuller sound than the more stripped sound of \\"Get behind me satan\\".<br /><br />The blues influenced \\"You Don't Know What Love Is (You Just Do What You're Told)\\" flows effortlessly, while the horn peppered \\"Conquest\\" is a cover (rare for the Stripes) of a Patti Page song; it features fab trumpet layering to give a band effect and a duelling guitar/trumpet solo over a pseudo mariachi rhythm (you can almost picture Jack in a poncho and sombrero).<br /><br />\\"Rag and bone\\" is a power house featuring both Jack and Meg on vocals (his southern drawl nicely contrasted by her whispering) and is brilliant! Just as rocking is \\"Little cream soda\\" with its thumping beat, crashing cymbals, and spoken delivery.<br /><br />\\"Prickly Thorn, But Sweetly Worn\\" throws bagpipes (giving a Celtic touch) into the mix, aptly followed by the psychedelic \\"St. Andrew (This Battle Is In the Air)\\", a spoken piece (by Meg) set to percussion and bagpipes.<br /><br />\\"300 M.P.H. torrential outpour blues\\", and the brilliant \\"Catch hell blues\\" are (as their names imply) the most heavily blues tinged songs, the latter featuring interesting tempo shifts (gentle to explosive) and very interesting and exciting guitar work (from delicately plucked, to squealing guitars).<br /><br />\\"I'm a Martyr for My Love for You\\", a beautifully melodic song about an affair with a teenager that can never be, is the album's lone ballad. \\"I'm slowly turning into you\\" is a midtempo rocker with a blistering guitar riff, and lyrics recognizing how alike two people in a relationship become over time. Closing out is the brief country tinged \\"Effect and cause\\" with Jack having fun singing, even giggling.<br /><br />Much more accessible than the dark, experimental (even by the Stripes standards) \\"Get behind me satan\\" (which I loved, don't get me wrong), they are still pushing the musical envelope, something loads of acts seem unable to do these days. Look out, The White Stripes are back!!f country tinged \\"Effect and cause\\" with Jack having fun singing, even giggling. Look out, The White Stripes are back!!

0807014273|5.0|I originally bought this book knowing nothing about Frankl, his experiences, or psychological theories. I simply read the description and a few of the overwhelmingly positive reviews here on Amazon and decided that it sounded interesting. What a life-changing book. Merely reading it at any given time has a marked positive influence on my attitude towards life.   <br />  <br />What's most interesting about it, as Frankl says himself, is that what he's propounding are not abstract ideas developed by some academic at a university or in some research laboratory. He uses his direct experience in one of the most adverse circumstances possible--a Nazi concentration camp--to relate the ideas of logotherapy (his own school of psychotherapy) to the reader.   <br />  <br />In a nutshell, the three most important tenets of logotherapy are as follows: (1) Life has meaning under all circumstances--even the most miserable ones; (2) Our main motivation for living is our will to find meaning in life; and (3) We have the freedom to find meaning in what we do, and what we experience, or at least in the stand we take when faced with a situation of unchangeable suffering. These principles are put directly to the test, and Frankl demonstrates their validity in a way that no social scientist has conceived of (or been able to) ever before.  <br />  <br />From the afterword:   <br />  <br />\\"Frankl was once asked to express in one sentence the meaning of his own life. He wrote the response on paper and asked his students to guess what he had written. After some moments of quiet reflection, a student surprised Frankl by saying, 'The meaning of your life is to help others find the meaning of theirs.'  <br />  <br /> 'That was it, exactly,' Frankl said. 'Those are the very words I had written.'\\"

Alex Kernel (played by the amazing Daniel Br&uuml;hl) is a young disillusioned young man who, together with his fellow East Germans, are on the verge of a revolution and social change.<br /><br />While walking together with fellow rallyist, Alex was arrested and his mother, who witnessed the scene, suffered a heart attack. While his mother survived, it left her in a coma and for 8 months, Alex and his older sister Ariane took care of her. As East Germany became no more and the reunification of his homeland was completed, his mother woke up. What follows is a hilarious, amusing and at times serious and thought-provoking attempt to shield his mother from the sweeping changes and their altered life as citizens of the newly unified Germany.<br /><br />Director Wolfgang Becker spared no expense to capture a time and place that now exist only in old, yellowed newspapers and history books. The finished product, a film that is not only a realistic social commentary but also a love story between a son and a mother, and the journey a young restless soul need to travel to discover himself.
B000PKG6TE|4.0|Sounding revitalized, Josh Homme and company have returned with their fifth studio album, the lean, mean \\"Era Vulgaris.\\" Coming off the somewhat spacey \\"Lullabies To Paralyze,\\" the Queens Of The Stone Age sound more confident and more consistent than ever. Bookended by some of the band's grungiest work, \\"Era Vulgaris\\" does a superb job of blending the \\"Rated R\\"-era with the more popular, crowd pleasing material of \\"Songs For The Deaf.\\" To put it in short, this is the album that each and every QOTSA fan should appreciate.<br /><br />\\"Turnin' On The Screw\\" starts off the album with a down and dirty, somewhat perverted sound. Referencing \\"Silence Of The Lambs\\" and spouting off cliches left and right, Josh Homme sounds on top of his game. The groovier \\"Sick, Sick, Sick\\" and \\"I'm Designer\\" make up for what \\"Lullabies\\" was lacking, while \\"3's & 7's,\\" \\"Make It Wit Chu\\" and \\"Misfit Love\\" attempt to reinvent the typical Queens style, with all the sonic experimentation and trippy guitar parts you've come to expect by now. A few misses here and there don't hinder the album too much, thankfully. \\"River In The Road,\\" for example, lays on the cheese a bit with a constant siren blaring through the song, trying to make it sound badder than it actually is. Overall, \\"Era Vulgaris\\" is probably the easiest album of their catalogue to cut through, which can be taken as a good or a bad thing. Personally, I find it's a fun listen, a catchy, somewhat kitschy delivery of Queens' style hard-rock.<br /><br />\\"Era Vulgaris\\" may not be Queens' finest work, but it does serve as a reminder of all that they are capable of. Like all great albums, and every album they have recorded before it, it's the kind that takes a few good listen before it reveals itself. So give it a chance. It's worth the repeated spins, and at the very least, it gives you some silly artwork to chew on while you listen.
006112429X|4.0|This was certainly a compelling read--I finished it in a weekend, when I should have been attending to other things. Although it picked up elements from many school massacres, the parallels to the shooting at Virginia Tech. were eerie, the picture of the shooter prescient. I was taken completely off guard by the surprise ending. Other reviewers have discussed its plot as an examination of parenthood in the United States, and it drew together all the conflicts that mothers, in particular, face in caring for their families. One of the most difficult conflicts to discuss is whether we feel anything other than joy in our children--boredom, dislike, disgust, frustration, hopelessness, regret. I call it a \\"comedy of manners\\" and gave it four stars because many of the characters, particularly the supporting ones, fit well-known stereotypes of suburban parents, teachers, and children from an upper middle class background in a good school. Kevin is almost too bad to be true, his sister almost too good, his father almost too hearty and baffled. Because the other characters are drawn broadly, the narrator, Kevin's mother, reacts to them broadly, without as much nuance as we usually encounter in the \\"real\\" world. I recommend the book without reservation, unless you are particularly squeamish or looking for something light and bright to read at the beach. It's simply riveting. Please don't give away the surprise ending if you recommend the book to others.

That and the emotional wallop packed by this recording is second to none.  Even if you have copies aplenty of Pictures, or Night on..., such as I do myself, please do not hesitate to pick up this recording as it is worth every dime.  If you are looking for an interesting counterpoint to Reiner's reading of Pictures or Night pick of Jose Serebrier's recording on Naxos.
B00062ZE3U|3.0|So, here's the thing: After the release of Enter and Mother Earth, Within Temptation decided to release a more commercially geared album that's completely different from their two previous releases. 0151013047|3.0|Mohsin Hamid's second novel is more polished in prose and stylistic maturity than his first. Using the retrospective monologue as his narrative medium, Hamid has crafted a post-9/11 reflection of a young Pakistani male torn between his adopted identity in America and his ethnic lineage. However, like the protagonist of his first novel, Moth Smoke, the Reluctant Fundamentalist is also part of the Pakistani elite and must therefore be considered as a minor representation of culture and society in Pakistan. Indeed, even among the expatriate community, the character of Changez, as a debonair management consultant, transformed by workplace woes in New York is highly rarefied.<br /><br />The smart play on the word \\"fundamentalist\\" that Hamid employs compares Wall Street \\"fundamentals\\" and \\"bottom-line\\" culture with the simplistic linear reasoning of the religious fundamentalists. But here is where we find the most significant missed opportunity of the novel. Absent from the narrative is any cogent reflection of theological underpinnings of fundamentalists cultures, apart from Changez's decision to grow a beard. Perhaps because of Hamid's own secular persuasion, he has conflated anti-imperialist sentiments of many secular Pakistani youth with \\"fundamentalist culture.\\" However, the absolutist ideologies that radicals such as Muhammad Atta employed were most certainly infused with a contortion of theological logic. Granted that these males were \\"educated\\" in the West but the catalyst in their turn to radicalism was not merely anti-imperialist sentiments but rather a vituperative view of other Faiths.<br /><br />As long as one is not mislead by the cover marketing of the novel and the cursory reviews that consider this a novel of terrorist transformation, readers will find this to be an engaging read of literary value

B000OYC3J8|4.0|At the end of the nineties with the resurgence of teen pop had enough stranglehold on music of the day, even respectful rock acts made over polished music with the songs loosing their emotional edge in the process. Then as the new millennium started, along came The White Stripes like a breath of fresh air with their credo of only recording songs that they would be able to play live which for the most part limited the band two just two instruments, Meg White on drums and Jack White on either guitar or piano, per song. Fell in Love with a Girl even closed out Rolling Stones 40 Songs that Change the World which was listed in chronological order.    Now on their sixth album, Icky Thump, the duo again doesn't stray to far from their mission statement as the cover is draped again in their trademark red, white, and blacks although the band does bring in some extra instruments this time around. Conquest, made famous by Patti Page, features mariachi type trumpets while Prickly Thorn, but Sweetly Worn, which bleeds into St. Andrews (This Battle Is in the Air), gets a Scottish feel to it thanks to some bagpipes. Despite the small departures, the album is exactly what you would expect from the group with influences of folk, blues, and seventies arena rock but still sounding fresh and new.    But the album isn't a starter kit for recruiting new fans. Even though it comes close with the album opener, the title track that will get your toes tapping, and closer, Effect and Cause, with a nice sit in a circle and jam type a vibe to it, the disk doesn't feature anything as easily accessible as Fell in Love with a Girl, Seven Nation Army, or My Doorbell. But I am sure true music fans do not care and will enjoy the album anyways.

0465043577|5.0|This book should be required reading for all of Wall Street's money managers. It would have saved billions of their clients' money.<br /><br />Let's look at the Long Term Capital disaster. Intelligent people, Nobel laureates, so what went wrong? The answer is simple: fat tails! (The concept that supposedly one-in-a-billion events are, in fact, not unusual). Clearly, it was not lack of intelligence that caused their downfall, but a childish reliance on flawed financial theories.<br /><br />Mandelbrot identifies and explains the flaws. True, he does not provide an alternative theory, but perhaps the whole point is that financial markets, being chaotic systems, are not predictable.<br /><br />Let's look at another chaotic system, the weather. Here the parameters such as temperature, wind speed, humidity, are easily measurable. Yet, we still cannot predict the weather accurately for more than a day or two. How then can the stock market, which is far more complex than the weather, be predictable, when most of the parameters that affect it are not measurable, and some are not even known?<br /><br />Perhaps the weakest part of the book is the beginning of a theory that Mandelbrot tries to found. He suggests that fractal equations produce charts that look and feel like real stock price charts, and that there might be some connection that can be exploited to predict or describe financial markets. He does not, however, go beyond this suggestion and hopes that someone else would develop his theory.<br /><br />Bottom line: Mandelbrot's \\"fat tail\\" theory explains the financial disasters suffered by many \\"brilliant\\" money managers. It does not predict the market, but explains the risks of conventional capital market theories. It saves you money, and after all a penny saved is a dollar earned.

0385522401|5.0|I've long had the opinion that with all the hundreds of books published and the movies produced that all of them put together hardly scratch the surface of human experience --- because 99% of them sidestep real human experience in favor of the slick commercial junk most publishers demand. My own life has been more full and complex than average, I dare say; but the main focus of it still remains a few hours on June 17, 1954; those few hours doing more to formulate the direction of my life than anythin before or since. Ian McEwan certainly knew what he was doing writing this great book. Finally, I don't believe his double-disclaimer that the characters are fictional and the hotel doesn't exist. B000OCXFCO|4.0|I must say that Megadeth had slightly disappointed me for a while. Proving that it was no fluke, \\"United Abominations\\" turned out even better.  I would say this is my third favorite Megadeth album behind \\"Rust in Peace\\" and \\"Peace Sells\\" although \\"Killing is my Business...\\" is about tied with this one.  The style isn't too much different from \\"The System Has Failed\\", but it's a little bit thrashier.  There's more songs like \\"Blackmail the Universe\\" and fewer songs like \\"Die Dead Enough\\".  As far as commerciality goes, it's somewhere between their underground stuff and their commercial stuff, just as \\"The System Has Failed\\" was. The band shreds like on their early albums, but the strong structures are a bit simpler and the choruses still have a little bit of that sing-a-long feel.  I know people are wary when they see the word \\"comeback\\", but trust me, this is no \\"St. Anger\\" (which, by the way, I don't strongly like or dislike - 2 1/2 stars).<br /><br />Here's my breakdown:<br /><br />1. Amerikhastan - 6/10 - This is a great song musically and I would have given it an 8 or a 9, but the long spoken passages really drag it down.  The chorus is nice as are the leads at the end, so I still like it.<br /><br />10. You're Dead - 5/10 - My least favorite song on the album.  A lot of people really like this one, so maybe I just to listen to it some more.  There really isn't much to comment on.  It's just a straight-forward thrash song that never fully clicked for me yet doesn't sound bad.<br /><br />11. Burnt Ice - 7/10 - This song is the one that's closest to their underground style, but it's not quite there stylistically.  It breaks from the traditional verse-chorus song format and it's worth listening just for the solos. Fun trip. Worth every penny....  <br />It'sworth the spice to buy!

0385522401|5.0|Mcewan's latest, \\"On Chesil Beach,\\" is the painstaking recounting of the wedding night of Florence and Edward, newlyweds in 1962. Very much in love, but inexperienced, Edward has waited for what seems like forever to make love to her; Florence meanwhile feels an inexplicable disgust for reasons McEwan only hints at. In a single evening, McEwan tells the story of their lives--one reviewer likened it to the thoughts of a typical day, as the mind flits from past to present to future and back again. The retelling is much more disciplined than that, however, and McEwan recreates a time and place with deft, concrete details--the food, the clothing, the cultural undercurrents.     This book is quite different from McEwan's other works. The events are rather ordinary, unlike the eery, macabre, and frightening plot lines of some of his other works. The hostility is verbal, muted, under the surface. It's more novella than novel, with only two characters fully drawn. But McEwan is masterful as always, and although the book can be finished in an afternoon, there are many layers and questions, a lot to speculate about. It's well worth your time.

0618680004|4.0|In his latest work, Dawkins explores the delusion humans in nearly all societies have shared throughout history - that of religious beliefs.<br /><br />In one interesting chapter, Dawkins postulates several possible and quite interesting evolutionary origins of religion that may help to explain why it has developed alongside civilization. He also addresses the absurd notion that religion is the root of morality, and demonstrates how traditional arguments in favor of God's existence are actually hollow products of wishful thinking. The underlying, despairing theme throughout the book is how, even today in the 21st century, religious beliefs persist in complete absence of reason.<br /><br />This is a very readable text; the reader need not be an expert in philosophy, biology or theology to appreciate it. It is an excellent resource for those having doubts about faith and who would like support in \\"escaping from religion\\" (to use Dawkins' own phrase) and thinking for oneself. I made my own break for it some time ago. :)
B000EF7W3Y|5.0|This is an album for the century. If there ever was to be a definitive top 100 in music of all time, then this would find a deserving place among the top 10. Molded from Irish melodies and European rock of the 80's, this is a superb make from the little known Waterboys. And forget gem, this deluxe double album is a diamond. Surprising when you go back to listen to what else The Waterboys have to offer from their rough and rocky career in music. I first became acquainted with them a couple of years ago when I watched the movie \\"Waking Ned Devine\\". A charming movie made several years ago, with the intro containing title track \\"Fisherman's Blues\\". Well I heard it and really liked it, a lot. So I went through the normal routine of checking them out here on Amazon to see what they had to offer. Surprisingly I was dismayed. Practically everything I listened to was hopelessly dated and without good melodies. A lot of it was just a load of electric sound. And then in the middle of it all, I discovered this. One would double take. I couldn't believe the difference between this and their other studio releases.     The product of a two year stay in Ireland was the crown gem of this band formed originally in London in '81. The whole demenor of the band changes in these two precious discs. The title track alone is enough to make believers out of those who love music, but it just keeps comming and there's such a variation. Every song has something different to offer. \\"We Will Not Be Lovers\\" is ominous, plagued with repetitious fiddle scratches that could have been overboard and may still be for some, but a very vigorous 7 min track. This I think, is close to what their non 'Irish' sound is like. But its still a good track. What follows is a gentle sea tune called \\"Strange Boat\\". I think Ireland's soothing qualities in surroundings were clearly at work with The Waterboys on this one. A complete 180 from the previous track. Probably the second best one on this disc. Next its back to bedlam with rigorous \\"World Party\\". Loud and electric. If you don't like it, skip to \\"Sweet Thing\\". This song has been done over by many great artists, collaborated on by Paul McCartney, John Lennon and Van Morrison while some including me say that The Waterboys' timeless version is ultimately the best, even topping Van's version. All I know is that I like it very much. It really is a timeless love song and continuing with the tradition of these first few tracks, long, at over 7 min. \\"Jimmy Hickey's Waltz\\" is one of a few really charming authentic Irish tunes that permeate this edition. These little outtakes help make the album special. Short and sweet. Lead singer Mike Scott, who is esentially The Waterboys, combines his trademark Euro sounding music with the Irish root influences in the next two tracks \\"And a Bang On the Ear\\" and \\"Has Anybody Here Seen Hank?\\". \\"When You Go Away\\" is very nice and subdued, and \\"Dunford's Fancy\\" is another Irish jig. On the twelfth track, Mike Scott does something special, singing \\"The Stolen Child\\" accompanied with this really great old authentic Irish voice. Now forgive me because I can't recall the man's name, but he does an excellent job in this song in a kind of narrating position. Good stuff. There is a bonus track on this disc, which is little more than an extremely short outtake of \\"This Land Is Your Land\\". But a part of what makes this album so charmingly rustic and earthy. And that's just the first disc folks! If you're going to buy this album then its worth it to shell out the extra few Bucks for the next 14 tracks, which are just as good. Beginning with a spirited and thoroughly Irish instrumental piece called \\"Carolan's Welcome\\" that builds until it is positively grand. There are a lot of songs on this CD that are labeled as 'outtakes', but which are really of studio quality. A couple of different versions of songs from the first disc like a slower sea shanty take on \\"Fisherman's Blues\\". \\"Girl Of the North Country\\" should have been included on the original album its so good. \\"Let Me Feel Holy Again\\" and \\"Meet Me At the Station\\" explore Scott's spiritual outpourings, which is the way a lot of his following material to this album turned out.     Some of you might turn out liking the second installment of this magnificent collection better than the first. It certainly holds a lot of merit. I don't know how some people can pass up the deluxe edition with all it has to offer. Simply a must have.    So there you have it. A true masterpiece. So true, this album has nothing to hide. Its completely honest. I'm telling you, this music is so spirited that you'll want it played at your funeral. It really touches you. Be sure to pay it well earned attention.     And thank God for the Irish (and this album).
B000OYC3J8|4.0|The White Stripes (and I despise it when people refer to them as \\"White Stripes\\") betrayed us with \\"Get Behind Me Satan.\\" The Iraq War was in its second year and all Jack White could give us was 13 tracks, all of which lacked any kind of lurching or even venomous flourishes? 0385522401|5.0|The strict social conventions of 1962 England coupled with flawed perceptions on how, in marriage, Edward and Florence envision they will frolic in new freedoms, ultimately forges a fateful and very forlorn finale.<br /><br />Tucked cozily inside a lovely Georgian Inn, following their wedding in July 1962, Florence Ponting and Edward Mayhew, loving newlyweds, each bring a lifetime of repressed desire and hidden baggage into their bridal suite on Chesil Beach.<br /><br />Florence is a talented violinist, a master at her craft, a craft she escapes to when confronted by conflict or fear. She is locked up inside of herself, unable to bear disappointing other people or expressing her emotional needs. She is happy to be free of the confines of her well-to-do, but rather dysfunctional family, but at the same time, she grapples with hiding her most intimate thoughts and repressed fears from her new husband. She wants very much to please him, but...can she?<br /><br />Edward is so smitten with his beautiful, lovely new wife, and all the new found upward opportunity that she has afforded him by their marriage. The higher social status of her family and the offer of a secure new job in her father's firm now await him. He also feels that he has escaped a life of confinement; albeit quite a different one from hers. His family struggles with trying to remain functional while dealing with serious flaws and hidden problems. He lovingly looks upon Florence as his deliverance and the answer to finally and fully be free of his pent up sexual frustrations.<br />He is uncertain how to properly seduce her and fears that he may, in his overly excited state, find his great dread of \\"arriving to soon\\" a reality.<br /><br />Both are so very eager to please each other, but also equally impossibly unable to express their innermost sexual fears and desires. This impassable situation is the critical point in McEwan's novella.<br /><br />What really happened on Chesil Beach that night?<br /><br />With superb narration, while sparing information that the reader must construct for himself, McEwan poses some very important questions on lost opportunities in our lives. In the most intimate of settings, the author very skillfully weaves complex truths and enables our empathy by careful understanding of what's 'playing' out in their heads. The music of each is indeed very different.<br /><br />How often we misinterpret others actions, attribute our expectations to others, do not always fully communicate our deepest feelings...out of personal insecurities or repressed fears?<br /><br />How a moment in time can forever change our destiny!ation that the reader must construct for himself, McEwan poses some very important questions on lost opportunities in our lives. B000DZIGDU|3.0|Anthony \\"Swoff\\" Swofford served in Gulf War One, and then came home to write about it. His gripping book, \\"Jarhead: A Marine's Chronicle of the Gulf War and Other Battles,\\" was quickly optioned to be a movie. Where the book captures the fleeting explosions of adrenaline that briefly hits you between countless days of tedium, the film version really loads up the tedium.<br /><br />Really, this uninspiring true-life take on being a soldier may be the most honest take on war ever filmed. There are no heroics. No moments of raging brilliance to stop an enemy. Just hot sweaty men in a desert, scared as hell and maybe bored beyond it. What that translates to is tedious viewing. War is the long stretches of nothing between battles, and these long stretches form the majority of \\"Jarhead.\\" If you're looking for \\"Saving Private Ryan,\\" \\"Platoon\\" or even \\"The Boys of Company C,\\" you're not getting any of that here. \\"Swoff\\" spends his entire stay in Desert Shield to Desert Storm wondering when he will finally get the chance to use his elite sniper training to make his first kill. The kill that never comes.<br /><br />\\"Jarhead\\" comes closest to mimicking the superior \\"[[ASIN:B00005ATQF Full Metal Jacket]]\\" in that the drollness of Swofford matches Private Joker in Kubrick's film. But \\"Jarhead\\" has no payoff. Theirs is a place where no point of view ever happens...what politics there are in the movie will come strictly from your own point of view. The film itself is visually stunning, I doubt if the scene where oil rains down on Swoff's unit in the night, the desert lit only from flaming oil wells will easily be forgotten, or the horrific \\"highways of death\\" recreation. (Google that reference for the background.) Jake Gyllenhaal gives an eerie performance, the emotions bubbling under his facade. (Almost as good as his turn in \\"[[ASIN:B00005JOFQ Brokeback Mountain]].\\")<br /><br />But again, I return to the movie's pace and subject matter. It really is too slow and random to be truly entertaining, and yet its lack of any real point of view makes it hard to really dig into the charachters here. 0385522401|4.0|Once again, Ian McEwan demonstrates his sharp attention to detail and clear insight into the human psyche in his latest novel, On Chesil Beach. As newlyweds Edward and Florence share their first night together - a first experience for both - McEwan's lyrical writing reveals to us their unspoken fears about the consummation of their marriage, while also weaving in details about their childhoods, their courtship, and, ultimately, the tragic consequences that await them as a result of their inability to communicate on their first fated evening.    Though this is a novel about sex, McEwan does not limit its focus to merely the act itself, but rather connects it to the larger issues faced by Edward and Florence in their effort to connect with each other. Although Edward and Florence believe themselves deeply in love with each other, their wedding night reveals that they really don't know each other as well as they thought. As each focuses on pleasing the other, both physically and emotionally, they both sacrifice part of themselves. The resulting frustration and disappointment are not, as some reviewers have suggested, an effort by McEwan to glorify the sexual revolution of the 1960s and `70s, but rather his attempt to portray honest and unhindered communication as the most important element in a relationship, without which true love and happiness are not possible. In fact, McEwan demonstrates the harmful excesses of the '60s and `70s through Edward's own disenchantment with the era, placing the novel's only hope for romantic happiness and fulfillment on the virginal marriage between Edward and Florence. He also implies that, while a lack of communication can be detrimental to a marriage, too much of a focus on sex can be just as harmful.    On Chesil Beach is not McEwan's strongest work. The ending is abrupt and unfulfilling, and the actions of the characters are at times difficult to believe and empathize with. While McEwan's description of Edward and Florence's encounter is not gratuitous, some of his details are cringeworthy and provide more information than we need to know. And, since this is a short novel - more of a novella - there is neither the plot nor character development found in Saturday or Atonement. Yet McEwan's well-shaped sentences and carefully crafted passages are always a pleasure to read, and the writing in On Chesil Beach is just another testament to McEwan's finely honed skill.
B000002UAR|5.0|Okay: I was six when the Beatles first washed ashore over here in '64; their records have been a part of my life ever since. Quite simply -- and don't argue with me here -- Revolver is the single best album of the rock era. EVER. And I mean that for both the American AND UK versions.     You're listening to genius from track to track that doesn't let up. It was the album that split the Beatles' career in two -- from the touring, \\"I'm in love, yeah yeah yeah, hold my hand\\" Beatles to the older, more analytical Beatles.    Indeed, the last line of the last song on Revolver, \\"Tomorrow Never Knows,\\" is \\"Play the game existence to the end of the beginning.\\" Maybe Lennon didn't know it, but putting that line at the end of that album was a hint that things were changing, and we -- as well as the Beatles -- were never going to be the same again.     Sgt. Pepper was important, but it couldn't have even EXISTED without Revolver at the end of the beginning.     If you're just discovering the Beatles, start here.

038572179X|5.0|Ian McEwan is possibly the most adept novelist of the current era. His craftsmanship is on full display in this, his best developed, book.<br /><br />As a fan of McEwan's canon of work, I think Atonement serves as the best example of his creative maturation. Unlike other authors of this period in fiction, his skill is never over-the-top, always subtly present. One image, the description of pond scum in a battlesight, is breathtaking in its simplicity and directness.<br /><br />There were several times throughout this book that my breath was stolen. McEwan gets it so right so often, it is like taking a masters class in fiction. The characters are well-developed, the dialogue is beautiful and accurate, the history is never over-bearing and the themes are wonderfully crafted. I highly recommend this book!
